variant.question: You are the pilot of a modern, large turbojet aircraft. In an extended cruise, with the autopilot and all systems operating correctly, what must you do to maintain longitudinal trim of the aeroplane?

options.text: Nothing, the autotrim system will ensure the standing loads on the elevator are removed.
As fuel is used from the wing tips, the CG will be moving forwards, so you must periodically trim nose-up.
Periodically disconnect the autopilot and trim out any standing loads on the elevators.
As fuel is used from the wing roots, the CG will be moving backwards, so you must periodically trim nose-down.

variant.question: An aircraft dispatched with an unserviceable DFDR may complete ___ consecutive flights before the DFDR is repaired.
The reading of a Mach indicator is independent on

options.text: the outside temperature
the static pressure
the total pressure
the differential pressure measurement

variant.question: Which one of the following statements is true with regard to the operation of a Mach trim system

options.text: It only operates above a pre-determined Mach number.
It operates to counteract the larger than normal forward movements of the wing centre of pressure at high subsonic airspeeds.
It operates over the full aeroplane speed range.
It only operates when the autopilot is engaged.

variant.question: The Mach trim system allows to

options.text: increase the longitudinal static stability of the aircraft by changing the horizontal stabilizer according to the Mach number.
search for the ideal CG location by transferring the fuel into the horizontal stabilizer.
interlock the operation of the stick shaker at the oncoming of the high speed stall.
trim the pitch-up tendency at a high Mach number.

variant.question:
Concerning a fail-passive flight control system, in the event of a failure
1) there may be a significant deviation of flight path or attitude.
2) there is no significant deviation of flight path or attitude.
3) there is no significant out-of-trim condition.
4) there may be a significant out-of-trim condition.The combination that regroups all of the correct statements is

Refer to figure. 
 What must the pilot be particularly careful about in the current situation?

options.text: The autopilot could capture the glideslope before the localiser and commence descent outside of the protected area.
The Flight Director is in VOR/LOC but the autopilot is in Heading mode.
The autopilot could capture the localiser before the glideslope and commence a turn outside of the protected area.
The Flight Director is in Heading mode, but the autopilot is in VOR/LOC.

variant.question: The initial phase, when talking about an engaged autopilot mode, is the phase where the...

options.text: attitude is changed to obtain a new trajectory.
pilot is programming the autopilot on the ground before take-off.
aircraft maintains a set parameter.
aircraft is waiting for a certain set of parameters to engage the mode in question.

variant.question:
How can you disengage autopilot?1) disengage fly by wire. 
 2) press and hold priority button. 
 3) disengage on MCP. 
 4) forcefully move the control column.
For an aeroplane fitted with mechanical flight control system, the automatic pitch trim system:

options.text: is active whenever the autopilot is engaged.
is active whenever the autopilot is disengaged.
is active whenever the autopilot is armed.
is active whenever the flight director is engaged.

variant.question:
When flying a fly-by-wire aeroplane manually, the automatic pitch trim system eliminates the need for the pilot to make control column inputs to compensate for:
1. a windshear
2. slats/flaps configuration changes
3. thrust changes
The combination that regroups all of the correct statements is:
What is the purpose of the trim system?

options.text: To relieve forces on the controls while maintaining aircraft attitude.
To allow the pilot to make small attitude adjustments WITHOUT moving the flight controls.
To allow the autopilot to trim the aircraft in all 3 axes.
To automatically compensate for loss of an engine, or fuel imbalance.

variant.question: What is the purpose of the trim system?

options.text: To relieve forces on the controls while maintaining aircraft attitude.
To allow the autopilot to trim the aircraft in all 3 axes.
To allow the pilot to make small attitude adjustments WITHOUT moving the main fight controls.
To automatically compensate for loss of an engine, or fuel imbalance.

variant.question: Mach Trim is a device to compensate for:

options.text: the backward movement of the aerodynamic centre at high Mach numbers by moving the stabiliser to nose-up.
weight reduction resulting from fuel consumption during the cruise
the effects of temperature variation during a climb or descent at constant Mach
the effects of fuel transfer between the main tanks and the tank located in the horizontal tail

variant.question: Mach Trim is a device to compensate for:

options.text: the backward movement of the aerodynamic centre at high Mach numbers by moving the stabiliser to nose-up
weight reduction resulting from fuel consumption during the cruise
the effects of fuel transfer between the main tanks and the tank located in the horizontal tail
the effects of temperature variation during a climb or descent at constant Mach

variant.question: What is the green band/area on a pitch trim indicator?

options.text: The range within which the stabiliser trim should be set for take-off.
The range within which the stabiliser should be set for landing.
The allowable range for normal operation.
The maximum range of trim that can be set by the autopilot.

variant.question: What is the green band/area on a pitch trim indicator?

options.text: Range within which the stabiliser trim should be set for take-off.
Allowable range for normal operation.
Maximum range of trim that can be set by the autopilot.
Range within which the stabiliser should be set for landing.

variant.question: A Mach trim system...

options.text: compensates for Mach tuck caused by the rearward movement of the shock wave as an aircraft accelerates.
compensates for the forward movement of the centre of pressure, due to the forward movement of the shock wave, as speed increases.
compensates for Mach tuck by trimming the stabiliser down.
is activated by the pilot when reaching the limiting Mach number to trim attitude.

variant.question: During an automated en-route flight, the autotrim fails. What are the implications of such failure?

options.text: The autopilot should disconnect, with an associated warning for the situation. The pilot flying must be ready to take controls.
The pilot must disconnect the autopilot and take the control of the aircraft in order to avoid a runway autotrim condition.
The pilot flying should pay close attention to the CG, and be prepared for the aircraft to be out of trim in case the autopilot is disengaged.
The autopilot will automatically switch to the backup autotrim.

variant.question: The automatic trim is a component of the autopilot pitch channel. Its function is to:

options.text: transfer a stabilised aeroplane to the pilot during autopilot disengagement.
automatically disengage the autopilot in the case of an excessive pitch up.
set the attitude to an instantaneous value before engaging the autopilot.
reset the attitude, after engaging the autopilot.

variant.question: The automatic trim is a component of the autopilot pitch channel. Its function is to:

options.text: transfer a stabilized aeroplane to the pilot during autopilot disengagement.
automatically disengage the autopilot in the case of an excessive pitch up.
reset the attitude, after engaging (the autopilot).
set the attitude to an instantaneous value before engaging the autopilot.

variant.question: The purpose of the Mach trim system is to counteract:

options.text: The pitch down tendency at high Mach number.
Thrust oscillations at high Mach number.
The pitch up tendency at high Mach number.
Dutch roll oscillations.

variant.question: An aeroplane is equipped with an overspeed envelope protection system. This system is able to: - reduce the thrust setting to idle. - produce an automatic pitch-up signal. - inhibit pitch-up trim.

options.text: 2 only
3 only

variant.question: On a fly-by-wire aeroplane, what does the automatic pitch trim system do?

options.text: If the PIC changes pitch attitude and, at the desired attitude, releases control pressure, the system holds that new attitude.
It trims the aeroplane, if the autopilot has been engaged.
It performs the rotation during take-off.
If the PIC changes pitch attitude and then releases control pressure, the system maintains the current pitch rate setting.

variant.question: On a fly-by-wire aeroplane, what does the automatic pitch trim system do?

options.text: If the PF changes pitch attitude and, at the desired attitude, releases control pressure, the system holds that new attitude.
It trims the aeroplane, if the autopilot has been engaged.
If the pitch attitude is alternated and control pressure released, the system returns to the previous pitch rate setting.
It performs the rotation during take-off.

variant.question: The automatic pitch trim: - ensures the aeroplane is properly trimmed when the autopilot is engaged. - permits the elevator to always be in neutral position with respect to horizontal stabiliser. - ensures the aeroplane is properly trimmed when the autopilot is disengaged. The combination regrouping all the correct statements is:
What does the automatic pitch trim system of a conventionally controlled aeroplane do?

options.text: It moves the trim to relieve any constant loads on the elevator control.
It directs the pilot how to reset the trim when a constant load on the elevator control is detected.
It is an automated system ensuring correct rate of rotation during take-off.
It compensates for incorrect pilot inputs.

variant.question: The purpose of a trim system of a large transport aeroplane is to:

options.text: adjust the neutral position of a control surface.
move the control commands when the autopilot is engaged.
have the same manoeuvrability with the left or the right control command.
automatically extend the slats when approaching the stalling speed.

variant.question: What does the automatic trim system consist of?

options.text: A hydraulically controlled screw jack on the horizontal stabiliser.
Servo-assisted pressure added to the flight controls by the autopilot.
Hydraulically controlled trim tabs on the elevator.
Fuel being transferred forward or aft.

variant.question: Which of the following are functions of the automatic pitch trim? - Offload any steady elevator deflections - Reduce the steady load on the rudder control surface as much as possible - Cancel out off-trim conditions The combination regrouping all correct statements is:
In order to protect an aeroplane from exceeding limits, a Mach trim system is installed and:

options.text: Offers a pitch up moment.
Is used to counteract Dutch rolls.
Protects in case of an impending stall.
Offers protection against pitch up moments.

variant.question: The purpose of a trim system is to adjust the aerodynamic forces on the control surfaces..

options.text: so that the aircraft maintains the set attitude if the controls are released.
so that less force is required to move the controls.
and is used to rotate the aircraft during go-around.
and is used to rotate the aircraft during take-off.

variant.question: The purpose of a trim system is to adjust the aerodynamic forces on the control surfaces...

options.text: so that the aircraft maintains the set attitude if the controls are released.
so that less force is required to move the controls.
and is used to rotate the aircraft during take-off.
and is used to rotate the aircraft during go-around.

variant.question: You are flying manually in a fly-by-wire aircraft equipped with automatic pitch trim. You do not need to move the control column when: - you encounter wind shear. - you change the aircraft configuration (flaps, slats). - change the power/thrust setting. Select the correct combination of statements:

options.text: 1 only
3 only

variant.question: What is the purpose of the Mach trim system?

options.text: To correct for the rearward movement of the centre of pressure above a certain Mach number.
To prevent the rearwards movement of the shock wave at high speed.
To trim the stabilizer nose-down at high Mach numbers.
To move the centre of pressure backwards with increasing Mach number.

variant.question: When is the Mach trim activated?

options.text: When the centre of pressure moves rearward due to the formation of shock waves at high speed.
When shock wave formation occurs further along the profile at higher speeds.
To move the centre of pressure aft when shock waves occur in exactly that position.
When the centre of pressure is too far forward to allow for the formation of shock waves.

variant.question: Regarding a trimmable horizontal stabiliser on a large transport aeroplane, the most common basic design is that the horizontal stabiliser..

options.text: is moved by a hydraulically actuated jack.
is moved by hydraulically actuated control tabs.
moves in response to lateral control column/stick movement.
trim is adjusted by control tabs.

variant.question: What is the “autotrim”?

options.text: It is a function of the autopilot pitch channel to reduce control forces and hinge moments.
It blocks the elevator to prevent inadequate trim settings.
It is a separate servo actuator that ensures neutral trim of the elevator when the system is engaged.
It is a speed-dependent system which uses the ailerons or spoilers for roll trim.

variant.question: The purpose of an aeroplane automatic trim system is to position the stabilizer automatically to off-load the:

options.text: elevator.
rudder.
elevator and rudder.
elevator, rudder and ailerons.

variant.question: The purpose of an aeroplane automatic trim system is to position the stabiliser automatically to off-load the:

options.text: elevator.
elevator, rudder and ailerons.
rudder.
elevator and rudder.

variant.question: In the automatic trim control system of an autopilot, automatic trimming is normally effected about the:

options.text: pitch axis only.
roll and yaw axes only.
pitch, roll and yaw axes.
pitch and roll axes only.

variant.question: A visual and aural warning of runaway trim requires...

options.text: immediate action to stop the runaway. The aircraft must be configured for landing, using the non-normal checklist.
the autopilot to be left engaged for the approach and landing, as manual control may require excessive manual forces.
disconnection of the autopilot, and manual trimming fully forward, to retain control full flap must be used for landing.
NO action, as the autopilot will reset the trim once it has isolated the auto-trim system.

variant.question: What is the purpose of a trim system on large transport category aeroplanes?

options.text: To adjust the neutral position of a trim surface.
To move the control surfaces while the autopilot is engaged.
To automatically extend the slats when the aeroplane approaches the stall speed.
To provide the same manoeuvrability whether the left or right controls are in command.

variant.question: A Mach trim system, in order to protect an airplane from exceeding limits:

options.text: offers a pitch up moment.
is used to avoid Dutch rolls.
protects in case of an impending stall.
offers protection against pitch up moments.

variant.question:
What should a pilot do when exceeding V~MO~/M~MO~?
1. Reduce power to idle2. Use the pitch trim3. Give a nose-up input
The combination regrouping all correct statements is
If the aircraft is in the wrong configuration prior to take-off, not allowing a safe take-off, the pilots will get:

options.text: Aural alert on initial take-off run.
A visual warning near V~1~ or V~R~.
Visual alert on initial take-off run.
An aural warning near V~1~ or V~R~.
